intro: Thelocactus buekii subsp. jarmilae, commonly known as the Jarmilae thlocactus, is a rare and specialized cactus native to a very limited geographic region in northern Mexico. It is characterized by its compact, globular stem and a dense covering of spines, which provide protection from herbivores and extreme environmental conditions. The plant produces small, yellow flowers during the spring, which are typically short-lived but attract specific pollinators. Due to its restricted habitat and sensitivity to environmental changes, it is considered endangered and requires careful conservation efforts. Its botanical features make it an important subject for studies on desert flora and evolutionary adaptation.
